 In 2005, consumers spent 115% as much as they earned. The savings rate has declined to below 0. Can consumers continue to increase spending when their income is declining and the source of their borrowing is declining in value? Will production continue to increase if consumers' ability to purchase that production decreases? Will capital investment increase if purchase of the production it facilitates decreases?

While I do applaud this post in particular, and the statistics are welcome, I think we would interpret these facts in a very different manner, and I find many of the solutions you propose as more problematic than even Bush's incompetence. This is a matter of theory, and while I don't pretend to know who exactly you have drawn from in the pieces you write, much of it is fallacious.
 
 ie
 
The following is an example. Let's say a company produces items that sell for $100 with a production cost of $10, including $8 of labor cost. Let's say the company can sell 1,000 of these per day. How many workers will be hired? Enough workers to produce 1,000 items per day.
 
 Let's change one variable. Lets increase the labor cost to $28 per item, making the total production cost $30 per item. How many workers will be hired? Enough to produce 1,000 items per day. The SAME number as before, when labor costs were only $8 per item. 

 
 A company has many choices. It is not the choice of producing "1000 items for $100 each or nothing", it may produce less items at a higher price, more items at a lower price, it may replace workers with machinery, or abandon the field altogether to open business in a less labour intensive market.
 
 Let us ignore for the moment these last two alternatives.
 
 Suppose I can sell 1000 items for $100 each, or I could sell 500 items for $150 each, and that for the sake of argument this requires half the amount of labour, while other costs remain steady. If my labor costs are only $8 per good, I will choose the first option - invest $10,000 and reap $90,000 in profit (rather than invest $6000 and reap $71,000 in profit). 
 
 But if my labor costs are $28 per item, the first option costs me $28,000 in investment for $52,000 in profit. The second option costs $15,000 in investment for $60,000 in profit. 
 
 I would be wise as an employer under such circumstances to fire a full 50% of my workforce and reap the rewards, the second 50% are simply costing me money. Given less dramatic wage changes the number of employees affected will be smaller, but they will always be affected.
 
 It is simply fallacious to assume that the price of goods sold and the amount produced will remain constant - this may be true in a dictatorship, but in the market economy rising wages always results in a reduced demand for labour.
 
 The idea of a "profit eliminating wage level" is also fallacious, as there is not a single wage level that will suddenly make all or most businesses unprofitable. There are businesses which are barely profitable, that even a small change in wage rate will make them unprofitable, there are others that are very profitable, such that even a large change could be withstood. I find it ironic that economic "populists" such as yourself endorse laws which would wipe out small businesses and leave only large corporations remaining.
 
 
INVESTMENT DOES NOT CREATE JOBS
 
 Investment does not create jobs. Companies do not hire workers because they can "afford" them. Companies hire workers when they need them, and only when they need them. 

 
 And when do businesses need workers? When those workers are sufficiently productive to justify their wages. What determines to a great extent the productivity of labour? The level of investment of course. A man working a 100 million dollar piece of machinery in a car factory is about 1000 times as productive as a man attempting to fabricate a sports car by hand. Accordingly it will be in the interests of companies who have a high degree of capital investment to hire workers when it is not in the interests of companies which do not to do so.
 
 In a free market such investment cannot be said to "create jobs" per se, since there is a near infinite supply of jobs available, it "merely" raises the wage rate. In a mixed economy though where there is a legislated or union enforced minimum wage, the level of capital investment to a large extent determines the unemployment rate. Which is why to introduce 1st world minimum wages in nations without much investment will result in mass unemployment.
